item.title: Comment on Have the vibes shifted back? by Pillow Lasers
item.description:
Reply to Evan:

Well it is now clear no one knows what is meant by vibes in this context. The original post was about "why the Democrats are not doing better." now that they are doing better, we can only ascribe it to them adapting to your sense of the "vibe."

This non-rigorous style seems to attract the same in the comments. The Trumpian right so "intellectually alive." Fecundity is easy when you embrace obscurantism and the nihilistic empirics of Trump himself.

Political scientists already have a concept that explains the "vibe shift": the thermostatic theory of public opinion (https://www.niskanencenter.org/how-does-the-public-move-right-when-policy-moves-left/), where public opinion shifts in the opposite direction of policy change and the policy preferences of the party in power. When liberals are in power, public opinion shifts right. When conservatives are in power, they shift left.

It's also the norm that presidential candidates try to present themselves as being lined up with the median voter on valence issues and moderate their policy positions in a few key areas to help win over the median. Here's a nice songify of the Obama and Romney convention speeches to illustrate this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ekQSpbwKkdg.

But of course Walz isn't going to emphasize his most progressive policy proposals in MN when democrats had unified control. And of course Harris isn't going to talk up her most progressive policy proposals from her days in San Francisco or even in the Senate! Just like Romney didn't talk about his liberal policies as governor of MA when he ran for the Republican ticket! Or how Biden also did his best to present himself as moderate when he ran in 2020.

I just saw this all as the median voter theorem playing out like it always does. Perhaps TC will reply "of course this is happening, but the median voter has moved to the right on wokeism, AKA the vibe shifted." My response: sure, but again, that's thermostatic public opinion, which has been a documented phenomenon for decades in poli sci, such that it's covered in nearly every intro American politics textbook.

The sentence "I believe the kids call this 'cope.'" is using modern internet slang to comment on the blog post's argument. Let me break it down:

1. "Cope" is internet slang that originated from the word "coping," as in coping with a difficult situation.

2. In internet culture, especially among younger users, calling something "cope" implies that someone is trying to rationalize or comfort themselves in the face of an unpleasant reality, rather than accepting it.

3. The phrase "I believe the kids call this..." is a common way for older individuals to introduce slang or cultural references associated with younger generations.

In the context of this blog post, the commenter is suggesting that the author's analysis is a form of "cope." They're implying that the author (Tyler Cowen) is rationalizing or trying to comfort himself about political changes he might find uncomfortable, rather than accepting a shift in political dynamics that the commenter believes is occurring.

This comment is likely disagreeing with Cowen's assertion that "the vibes have [not] shifted back at all." The commenter seems to think that Cowen is engaging in wishful thinking or self-comforting analysis, rather than accurately assessing the political landscape.

It's worth noting that this kind of comment is often used dismissively in online discourse, and doesn't necessarily engage with the substance of the argument being made.​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

1. Scarcity of posts and small community. X is tiring + way too many random people. The community here is closest thing to a digital neighborhood or social club
2. Visitors all largely intelligent and diverse backgrounds, but largely shared core beliefs. No one (jinx) is arguing about capitalism vs communism.

Thesis: the chaos acts as sort of a captcha to filter for people who are resistant to it and can ignore it to focus on substance?

3. The pseudonym mechanism makes you willing to contribute meaningful stuff than something ephemeral like an image board
4. At end of day it’s often entertaining. HN and LW have interesting links but far too stifling and self-righteous conversation IMO.
5. TC / AT don’t seem desperate for you to comment, and in fact you get the gist it’s a bit of a playful love / hate relationship

———

I’m surprised no one’s made an anonymized-reputation social media. I weigh what Ackman says over a random, but there’s stuff Ackman or Eric Adams etc would only say if they were anon, but we’d never see it

You can solve this by allowing Bill etc to switch to a pseudonymous or one-time identity for a post where:

A) Bill can choose to display a tag that the post is coming from either a verified billionaire or someone with 1M+ followers. Maybe even offer an LLM feature that scrambles writing style to reduce Bill having to worry about dox risk.

B) The algo boosts the posts as if the profile had hundreds of thousands of followers

You could imagine lots of interesting anonymous posts on X from verified senior politicians, people in gov, top corps etc

I am surprised, given his focus on free speech, that Elon hasn’t launched something like this; imagine how many interesting insights we could get.
